Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Cog-TV: Business and Technical Analysis of Cognitive Radio TV Sets for Enhanced Spectrum Access

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Today's wireless networks are facing an emerging spectrum crisis due to increased demand. FCC has recently allowed non-licensed devices to operate in the TV spectrum band, leading to cognitive radio networks (CRNs). It is argued that CRNs result in a technical and economical conflict with the TV broadcast companies, which own licenses to the TV spectrum. In this project, CRNs are considered as a business opportunity for broadcast companies. The answer to the following question is sought: "Is it economically and technically viable for broadcast companies to utilize TV white spaces for low-cost Internet provision and web-enabled TV services?" To facilitate the involvement of broadcast companies in the cognitive radio business, the concept of cognitive radio-enabled TV set (Cog-TV) is considered. Cog-TV provides low-cost access to the Internet and local area network capabilities. Cog-TVs are assigned optimal spectrum sensing schedules to provide service differentiation capabilities through a novel neighborhood watch concept. Dynamic pricing techniques are developed with the objective of distributing the peak-time demand load. Moreover, the cost of building the Cog-TV infrastructure in urban and rural areas is analyzed to determine its economic feasibility. Through this architecture, broadcast companies can leverage their channel ownership to create a competitive advantage.

The results from this research are expected to enable transformative and economically viable CRN development and management approaches. The Cog-TV concept has the potential to bring affordable Internet service to a large group of American households and impact consumer market by creating a niche market in new TV sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today's wireless networks are characterized by a fixed spectrum assignment policy and a large portion of assigned spectrum is utilized sporadically. To address emerging spectrum crisis due to increased spectrum demand, FCC has allowed Television Band Devices (TVBDs) to operate in TV spectrum band. It is argued that emerging cognitive radio network (CRN) solutions result in a technical and an economical conflict with TV broadcast companies, which own licenses to TV spectrum. In this project, this development is considered as an opportunity for broadcasting companies instead of a conflict, to answer the following question: Is it economically and technically viable for broadcasting companies to utilize TV white spaces for low-cost Internet provision and web-enabled TV services?


To this end, the concept of cognitive radio-equipped TV set (Cog-TV) is considered. Cog-TV is a next-generation integrated TV concept that will provide low-cost access to Internet, dynamic pricing of Internet service based on available capacity and projected demand, and wireless connectivity by utilizing licensed bands when they are not in use.


In CRNs, high performance is highly dependent on quality of spectral information. Yet, channel sensing results at different times, frequency bands, and locations carry high levels of correlations. Such correlations can be leveraged to sustain high quality sensing results while reducing energy consumption associated with sensing. It is found that approximately 20-40 SUs are needed to achieve probability of false alarm of 0.1, while random selection needs more than 100 SUs. Large variation in mean (i.e. pathloss) improves performance of scheduling algorithms in general due to increased diversity.


In addition to sensing, the additional capacity that can be provided by Cog-TV is analyzed. Cog-TV utilizes TV viewership information to identify channels that can be used without interference to TV viewers. In a geographical analysis of 274 major US cities, Cog-TV provides a 5.3-10.9-fold increase in average spectrum availability compared to FCC rules with a 2.7-5.0-fold increase in achievable capacity in high densitiy cities. Moreover, in a highly populated area such as Manhattan, we show that more than 97% of population can be provided with at least 3 additional TV channels (18 MHz) and as much as 40 (240 MHz) additional channels. Accordingly, Cog-TV can provide an average capacity of 244.2Mbps in Manhattan, New York City, which is 3.5 times of 69.6Mbps under FCC rules and higher than capacity of a WiFi network (802.11n) of 150Mbps.
The dynamic nature of the available white space capacity as well as the daily variations in Internet demand call for novel dynamic pricing schemes to maintain user demand below the capacity while increasing revenue. To this end, a dynamic pricing model is designed to capture the available channel capacity, the projected demand, and the number of customers carried over from the previous period. Based on these factors, an optimization model is built to determine the optimal price. The designed pricing models encourage novel downloading and streaming scheduling approaches for users to shift their high-load traffic to times when people do not watch TV.

For education and outreach, at UNL, the PI supervised a group of 6 undergraduate CS and CE students to design and develop a Cog-TV prototype as a part of a capstone project. The results of this work is presented as a demo in the IEEE DySPAN 2017 conference, exposing the students to a top academic conference environment. PI introduced concepts from software-defined radios and cognitive radio communications within the Advanced Sensor Networks, Wireless Communication and Networking, and Advanced Embedded Systems classes to senior undergraduate and graduate students. Groups of students designed and evaluated solutions including obstacle tracking, TV-band WiFi network, GPS spoofing; evaluated a handoff mechanism; measured coverage of active TV towers; and evaluated cooperative spectrum sensing mechanism for TV bands.

At OSU, the PI participated in the "Camp Engineer" program, which aims to introduce various engineering disciplines to middle-school students. Participating middle-school students have been introduced to the concept of spectrum sharing through a hands-on demonstration. PI has introduced the multi-model correlation models and their relation to cooperative sensing techniques in the graduate-level Wireless Networks course. The theoretical nature of the course lead to the discussion of Lyapunov-based optimization techniques in contexts other than network utility maximization.


The project aims to address an immediate challenge by focusing specifically on TV channels. Still, the solutions developed in this project has the potential to guide other licensed users such as emergency services and police to generate revenue with this new phenomenon. The project is conducted by an interdisciplinary team with extensive experience in operations management, decision sciences, wireless communication, networking, and optimization. The developed techniques have the potential to impact operation and business models of popular Internet streaming services such as Netix and Hulu while providing opportunities for these services to increase their customer base through low-cost TV spectrum Internet.
